author: WADA(West Africa Decentralized Alliance)
title: Planting Roots In Africa
description: Best solutions will come from the ground, but African devs lack infrastructure to push Cardano forward. Cardano community support is needed.

assessments.note: This proposal effects many west african countries with various approaches and indeed seems money well spent in order to have a big diversified effect

This is a big proposal to fund several local hubs in different countries in West Africa. I strongly agree that the infrastructure provided by the hubs once they are up and running are very important for further operations in the region. It's a great start and has the potential to have a big impact by providing local presence to easier reach out to local developers, among others and educate about Cardano, all clearly stated in the roadmap of the proposal.

This proposal builds further on an approved project from Fund2. 
Providing infrastructure in previously installed hubs is essential as otherwise it would impede the functionality of those hubs and render them somewhat obsolete. So it is important that an approved project continues to receive support until it is self-sustainable. 
In a fund challenge that is specifically dedicated to seed and grow Cardano in Africa, the creating and sustaining of hubs to reach out to the local public is mission critical and can be used as a foundation for further operations in the future.
This proposal meet Fund 5 Grow Africa, Grow Cardano Challenge. If implemented well this proposal will bring a lot of new people to use the Cardano platform.

Yes it does but I'm scoring it a 4 star based on the rationale that it seems to be more centered on the Western side of Africa, what then would happen to the Eastern, Southern and Northern?
If this proposal is funded, I'm not sure will be able to extend itself to these other regions in the sense that the budget stated, ie, 125,695$ wouldn't be enough! However, if it's of the intent to tackle one region and making sure that it's yielding a better results before attending to other regions then the proposal is on coarse. 
I'm saying this because, West Africa has the most weird and hypocritical countries ever when we talk about Technological Advancement. And this is so because, leaders operating in various countries like Ghana, Nigeria, Cameroon, Togo and many others are just corrupt and continues to be corrupt with no remorse.  
Instead, the citizens are much enthusiastic about Technological Advancement and Development but their barrier is that they're not getting the opportunity to meet corporate organizations who's got this passion and mission of training people to becoming developers! And the painful aspect is, these corrupt leaders turn deaf ears to their demands as citizens too. If this project attacks from the root "citizens" and provide strong education to the leaders in order for to understand, it will be wise as once they're enlightened, it will be easy for adoption, acceptance and adjustments.
Also, cost of infrastructure is one blow to the eye. Office spaces which are just for rent (unfurnished) could cost more than 10,000$ for just two years and and furnishing alone could cost sometimes more than 5,000$. Imagine if 10 countries/hubs are to be created simultaneously, each hub might consume not less than 30,000$. So 125,695$ wouldn't be enough right?
This proposal addressed the issue of legitimacy. I'll commend that approach but my only advice is, they should be extra vigilant in carrying out that exercise else they might end up spending more than supposed to. This is so because, once setting up of new agency is involved, whether profitable or non-profitable, several institutions will approach trying to you know get a cut of the cake. In Ghana for instance, the only institution to receive a legit certification and approval is the Office of the Attorney General. Further research must be done vigilantly to ensure smooth operation.

This proposal, I recommend that it be voted for! It will be fantastic to see their operations.

I rate a 4 in impact because the proposal identifies a specific way to address the challenge question. The proposal identifies the need for boots on the ground and outlines, in detail, a way to accomplish Cardano development within Africa. The proposal in deed identifies that this will add value to Cardano by allowing developers living in Africa to work on projects needed in the local communities. There are no key metrics which is what keeps me from rating the project a 5. I think it is a strong idea, the proposal lacks info required by the rubric.
The proposal is backed by an experienced team and has a detailed plan that seems tangible with great effort. I am positive that it can be implemented successfully.

In terms of feasibility, there is no question that there is already a large dedicated team behind this proposal. Details about the different regional leads are presented in a separate document and they have relevant experience. What could possibly be improved here would be a little more information on how big the individual teams are for the different hubs, but I do trust that they are all well supported from the overarching team. There is also a separate document with a detailed and reasonable looking budget for the different costs related to the individual hubs, covering both the starting one-time costs like equipment and ongoing costs for a time period of 3 months, which does mean that the hubs will need new funding to continue their operation and roadmap, either with another Catalyst proposal or by other means, so some more details about this and about the future sustainability would have made it even better. There are also very relevant local risks with setting up in the different regions, but it does look like the team has identified and taking the major ones into consideration.
The Proposers have the experience required to deliver this project. A relatively detailed cost breakout of the plan by location is provided.

WADA has been successfully installing hubs across western Africa since Fund2. Their project community works in close collaboration with other established projects, such as Gimbalabs, which adds to the sincereness and feasibility of the proposal. 
Prioritising cost items in terms of functionality assures a stable form of growth and early operability.
It is likely for this proposal to be implemented because it includes a straightforward plan which will serve the Cardano Community build momentum and growth in Africa.

Based on the experience and plans expressed above, it is feasible enough that this project can be implemented successfully. A little challenge might occur as obviously the budget might not be enough but I'm sure there's a plan B.

Proposal provides a detailed budget in a spreadsheet, short overviews of each team member, and the link to their project that is already ongoing. The budget is reasonable and there is a realistic time table. The proposal justifies the location for each "hub" they want funding for and finally, they address relevant risks and explain how to plan/adjust for each risk.

The project contains no unfeasible parts. There are a lot of various projects that need to be adressed, however as there is a whole organisation behind it. I am pretty optimistic the workload can be dealt with by those people. The impact of the project hence how it affects the challenge has the potential to be quite big, depending on how well the opportunities that are created by it are used

When it comes to auditability, this proposal has a clear roadmap and a vision of what success looks like. The funding requested covers the first 3 months of the provided roadmap, which is to get the hubs set up and started. The budget for the different hubs, which is provided in a separate document, is detailed, so it will be easy to audit. The team has also clearly stated that they are aware of the risks like the final costs being different or rather higher than anticipated and have a plan on how to correctly prioritize the funds to get working hubs if that's the case. The challenge metrics are also very relevant for this proposal and I don't think it will be difficult for them to provide the numbers of how many people are engaged with the different hubs once they have gotten started.

It would be useful to know how many people each of the 6 centers could actually help. Also what is the plan for these centers after the initial 3 months? Will this program require more Catalyst funding, or do we risk it collapsing and leaving people stranded?

The requested budget is steep, but the attached documents justify the amount. The budget size is intended to fund 7 hubs, which translates to ~17 956 USD/hub. 
What is missing to place a context around this is how many participants these hubs are designed to accomodate. 
Furthermore there is a very short mention of the infrastructure being needed to support stake pool operations. Which raises the question as to how long it is projected for this project to be support independent.
The information provided in the Roadmap is sufficient to track and audit the project. Quick question: How many curriculum do you plan to deliver?

Yes there's enough information on this project with regards to tracking of their progress and the success of it. Rationale being that they've broken the year into margins and assigned specific goals for every margin. Per that, auditing and close monitoring can be done in order to ensure progress and success.
In view of promoting Cardano, the approach of this proposal is basically one of the best I've across, reach out to the people, educate them to understanding and you'll realize the power of knowledge investment. That's why I'm content with their topic, "Planting Roots In Africa".

A few metrics appear throughout the proposal but there is not a clear set of KPIs to assess. Even without the KPIs there is a road map and a clear plan to expand WADA and to add to the Cardano space. This proposal allows for us to accept that we cannot predict the specific projects that will come out of the work, the same way that in 2000 we could not predict the dominance the iPhone would eventually have in the world today.

solution: Funding basic infrastructure in African hubs will allow us to collaborate, coordinate, educate and initiate building out local use cases.
